metadata.title: On the formation of AlSi10Mg single tracks and layers in selective laser melting: Microstructure and nano-mechanical properties

n the formation of AlSi10Mg single tracks and layers in selective aser melting: Microstructure and nano-mechanical properties
esma T. Aboulkhair a,b,∗, Ian Maskery a, Chris Tuck a, Ian Ashcroft a, Nicola M. Everitt b
Additive Manufacturing and 3D Printing Research Group, Faculty of Engineering, University of Nottingham, Nottingham NG7 2RD, United Kingdom Bioengineering Research Group, Faculty of Engineering, University of Nottingham, Nottingham NG7 2RD, United Kingdom
r t i c l e i n f o
rticle history: eceived 18 May 2015 eceived in revised form 20 October 2015 ccepted 19 November 2015 vailable online 24 November 2015
eywords: dditive manufacturing elective laser melting ingle tracks luminium alloys icrostructure anoindentation
a b s t r a c t
Selective laser melting (SLM) is a relatively new manufacturing technique that can be used to process a range of materials. Aluminum alloys are potential candidates for SLM but are more difficult to process than the titanium alloys more commonly used with this technique. This is because of the former’s physical properties that can result in high levels of porosity in the final parts. Although the majority of studies to date into the processing of Al alloys by SLM have considered the development of load bearing objects, in particular porosity reduction and mechanical characterization of the parts, it is also important to study the single tracks formed during the process. This paper studies the effect of changing the scan speed on the formation of fusion lines and single tracks from an Al alloy, as well as their overlap to form a single layer. The geometrical features of the melt pools as well as the boundaries of continuity and/or irregularities were defined and showed dependence on scan speed. Keyhole mode melting domination was observed. The scan tracks and layers were porosity-free suggesting pores to form with layer accumulation. Investigations showed that increasing the layer thickness should be avoided as it promoted defects. Energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) mapping was implemented to compare the chemical composition distribution in the SLM material and its as-cast counterpart. A fine microstructure with homogenous distribution of the alloying elements was observed. Nanoindentation and EDX were used to establish an understanding of the hardness profile across melt pools of single tracks and their interrelation to the chemical composition. The elemental distribution yielded uniform high nano-hardness with no spatial variation across the SLM material.
© 2015 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
. Introduction
Selective laser melting (SLM) is a form of additive manufacturing AM) that can be used to produce complex structures from metallic owder materials. One of the motivators for the current research n SLM is the need to manufacture the light-weight, geometrially complex structures required by the aerospace and automotive ectors. The SLM method involves building a part layer-by-layer hrough scanning a powder-bed with a laser beam. Yadroitsev et al. 2010) explained that a series of physical phenomena take place uring processing, such as laser radiation absorption and scattering, eat transfer, phase transformation, fluid flow within the melt pool riven by the surface tension gradient, and evaporation and emision of material. According to Hotter et al. (2012), when the laser eam irradiates a material, an energy balance between conductivity
∗ Corresponding author. E-mail address: emxntab@nottingham.ac.uk (N.T. Aboulkhair).
ttp://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jmatprotec.2015.11.016 924-0136/© 2015 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
and absorptivity exists, which governs the mode of melting, either keyhole or conduction mode melting.
In SLM a 3D part is built from a series of layers. Each layer is made up of adjacent scanned tracks referred to as melt pools. In other words, the part is built through the overlap and metallurgical bonding of lines into a layer and the layers into a part. Melt pools can be considered as circular or cylindrical segments (Yadroitsev et al., 2010), the stability of which dictates the quality of the part on the larger scale because it affects pore formation probability. Yadroitsev et al. (2010) attributed the stability of single tracks to variation in processing parameters, such as layer thickness, scan speed, laser power, substrate material, and the properties of the powders, based on experiments on various metal alloys. They (Yadroitsev et al., 2010) observed two types of instabilities in stainless steel scan tracks dominated by scan speeds and laser power; discontinuity/droplet formation at low scan speeds when using low laser power (25 W) and balling at high scan speeds when using high laser power (50 W). Yadroitsev et al. (2013) demonstrated the dependence of the geometrical features of 316L stainless steel
s ( b
ingle tracks on the energy density input. Yadroitsev and Smurov 2010) showed that the selection of a layer thickness is influenced y two main factors: the powder particle size distribution and the
extent of shrinkage during the process. Ciurana et al. (2013) used a tilted platform to investigate the effect of layer thickness, laser power, and scan speed, simultaneously, on CoCrMo single tracks
a t A r o m e b p a a l o d e o e r d t l
t z i t b
nd defined the threshold for the energy density to avoid single rack defects. There are fewer studies with attention focusing on l alloys. For example, Kempen et al. (2011) defined the major equirements to successfully produce a consolidated single track f AlSi10Mg as: (1) formation of a continuous track, (2) each layer ust lightly penetrate the layer below, (3) a layer must be high nough to cumulatively build the part, and (4) a connection angle etween each two layers should be ensured. The range of laser ower they (Kempen et al., 2011) investigated was between 170 nd 200 W. It is believed that when processing Al alloys with SLM,
high laser power is required for melting to substitute for the osses caused by the high reflectivity (91% (Macleod, 2001)) and to vercome the rapid heat dissipation due to the high thermal conuctivity (146 W m−1 K−1 (ASM, 2014)). Furthermore, Yadroitsev t al. (2010) stated that the use of high laser power allows a degree f freedom for the scan speeds employed. However, Aboulkhair t al. (2014) used double scan strategies at high scan speeds to educe processing defects, such as balling, and produce near fully ense Al parts with low laser power. So it is beneficial to invesigate the possibility of producing consolidated single tracks and ayers from Al alloys using lower laser power.
Although the majority of the work in the literature on single racks experiments is concerned with defects and defining the ones of regularity, these experiments could have greater signifcance. For instance, Bartkowiak et al. (2011) conducted single rack experiments to validate the feasibility of producing new lends of powder especially tailored for SLM as well as deter-
mine if there was oxidation of the surface during the processing of bulk parts. Loh et al. (2015) used information from Al6061 single track experiments to develop a simulation model that is helpful in understanding the heat transfer during SLM and further highlights the role of laser power and scan speed. Su and Yang (2012) performed a study on single layers to understand the overlap between layers, aiming at tracing porosity formation mechanisms in stainless steel 316L. A hypothesis was suggested by Dai and Gu (2014) that pores formed during processing copper matrix composites because of trapped gases in the melt pool. This is dependent on the energy density and it was suggested that they accumulate to become porosity in the bulk samples. However, this hypothesis was not verified using experiments on single tracks to show whether pores are formed in each melt pool or during the overlap of lines and/or layers through material remelting.
Nanoindentation is a depth sensing technique that is used to test mechanical properties of materials, such as nano-hardness and Young’s modulus (Fischer-Cripps, 2004). One of the characteristics of this test is that the depth of an indentation is in the micrometer range, which allows the determination of the properties of materials at a small scale. This could be beneficial in SLM due to the fine microstructure reported by Thijs et al. (2013) and distribution of phases. The application of this technique in SLM is not yet common and it has been mainly used to test the hardness of larger bulk parts, such as the work by Biedunkiewicz et al. (2014) on metal matrix composites processed by SLM.

This paper considers the effect of changing the scan speed on he melting and solidification of AlSi10Mg upon irradiation with
laser beam. The literature lacks information on the melting and olidification response of Al alloys to laser irradiation in SLM. The ork in the literature mainly focussed on stainless steels except for ew works, such as Kempen et al. (2011) who studied an Al alloy, hereas lightweight Al alloys are considered much more relevant n the field of additive manufacture. The response of the material to aser irradiation varies according to the physical properties of the arget material and so results from an investigation on one mateial cannot be generalized for all materials. The aim is to develop n understanding of the formation of single tracks and layers as n approach to tackle difficulties in producing flaw-free 3D parts. empen et al. (2011) focussed on developing the process window or producing a consolidated single track, i.e., processing-focussed. e examine whether porosity is formed due to the overlap of sin-
le tracks into a layer, or during the overlap of layers to form a art. This improves upon the conventional way in which porosity
s minimized in SLM parts by conducting prolonged experiments for arameters optimization. The study is divided into two parts; the rst studying fusion lines on a substrate without powder and the econd studying single tracks produced from powders. The depth f penetration and width of tracks as well as the response to changng scan speeds was determined. The continuity and regularity of he scan tracks was also investigated. The difference between the
icrostructure and chemical composition distribution in the SLM aterial and conventional as-cast material was explored. Nano-
ardness of both the SLM material and the as-cast material was easured and related to the microstructure to understand the icrostructure-property relationship. This paper therefore conributes to available research in the field of SLM in novel aspects y filling these gaps in the literature.
. Experimental work
A Realizer GmbH SLM-50 (Germany) selective laser melting achine equipped with a 100 W Yttrium fiber laser (YLM-100-
C) was used in this study. The spot size of the laser beam was 0 m at the focus position. The machine processes under argon tmosphere with a 0.1% oxygen level. An LM6 (Al-Si12%) as-cast ngot supplied by Nigel Smith Alloys Ltd., (UK) was used as a subtrate material. The substrate was polished and its surface was leaned with acetone before laser scanning. AlSi10Mg powder suplied by TLS Technik GmbH (Germany) was used to create single racks and layers. The properties of the powder are shown in Fig. 1.
ssed from a 400 m thick powder layer using 750 mm/s.
The particle size distribution is not significantly skewed toward smaller or larger size ranges, as determined using a Malvern UK Mastersizer 3000 (UK) that employs laser diffraction to measure the size of particles. Also, the morphology of the powder, imaged using a Philips XL30 scanning electron microscope (SEM) with a 20 kV accelerating voltage using a secondary electron detector, was spherical with minor satellites. This particle size distribution and morphology allows good flowability and packing density, as was demonstrated in a flowability test conducted using the Hall flowmeter funnel according to ASTM standard B213-13 (2013). The flowability index and apparent density for the powder were 62 s/50 g (adopting the static start to flow method) and 1.465 g/cm3, respectively. The chemical composition of the powder was 86.96% Al, 12.58% Si, and 0.46% Mg, determined by means of an energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) detector attached to the SEM. Compared to the standard, this powder had a Si content slightly higher than the expected range (9–11%Si). The higher Si content makes it a eutectic alloy (Murray and McAlister, 1984), which might affect the melting and solidification behavior during SLM as increasing Si reduces the surface tension of the alloy, as stated by Kempen et al. (2015).
A series of experiments were designed and conducted to study the response of the substrate material to laser beam irradiation through fusion lines (referred to as lines hereafter), the formation of single tracks (referred to as tracks hereafter), and single layers. These experiments are explained in Table 1.
The use of a 50 m hatch spacing for the single layers is based on a previous study by the authors (Aboulkhair et al., 2014) that showed that this hatch spacing successfully produced near fully dense SLM AlSi10Mg parts. The same reason justifies the use of a 40 m layer thickness. The motivation behind using a 400 m layer thickness is to define defects formed at large layer thicknesses. Topography of the lines and tracks was imaged using a Nikon Eclipse LV100ND microscope and SEM. Lines, tracks, and layers were cross-sectioned, polished, and imaged using optical microscopy. The geometrical parameters were measured from optical micrographs using the open source software ImageJ 1.46r (Abramoff et al., 2004). The microstructure of the tracks was revealed by Keller’s etch (Voort, 1999). A MicroMaterials LTD NanotestTM NTX Platform 2 nanoindenter was used to investigate the nano-hardness of the SLM material in a melt pool of a line produced using a scan speed of 500 mm/s. This speed was selected because it had previously been used to fabricate dense parts (Aboulkhair et al., 2014). Another line of indentations was conducted across melt pools in a single layer. A Berkovich tip was used for indentation. Indenter tip shape factor (diamond area func-

ion or DAF) was taken into account in the analysis as well as hermal drift pre and post indentation. Tests were performed in ccordance with the ASTM standard E2546-07 (2007) in a loadontrolled mode. The maximum indentation load was set to 7.5 mN nd the spacing between adjacent indentations was 15 m. The hemical composition was determined using EDX analysis for the ndented spots.
. Results and discussion
.1. Fusion lines on a substrate material
Lines created using various scan speeds are shown in Fig. 2. he line width decreased as the scan speed increased. Irregulariies and discontinuities appeared when increasing the scan speed eyond 500 mm/s. The insets in Fig. 2 demonstrate the irregulariies promoted by increasing the scan speed. As well as the widths f the lines, their depths also decreased with increasing the scan peed. The measurements for the geometrical parameters are repesented in the plot in Fig. 3a; showing the trend of size reduction ith increasing scan speed, i.e., melt volume decreases due to less nergy density delivered to the material. The melt pool was conical, ee Fig. 3b, rather than hemispherical, unlike other SLM candidate aterials observed by Yadroitsev et al. (2013). The depth to width spect ratio (see Fig. 3a) suggests keyhole mode melting rather than onduction melting as when keyhole mode melting dominates a elt pool, the depth to width ratio becomes larger than 0.5, as eported by King et al. (2014).
.2. Single tracks from AlSi10Mg powder
In SLM, a movable laser beam is used to melt the material. As a esult of this motion, the material flows in the assigned path of the aser beam. The material solidifies in a characteristic chevron patern denoting the direction of motion of the heat source, as shown n the micrographs in Fig. 4. Similar to the lines, the tracks’ widths
decreased with increasing scan speed from 250 to 750 mm/s, as seen in Fig. 4. Also irregularities formed at 750 mm/s. In the crosssectional views of the tracks in Fig. 5, the overall height of a melt pool was divided into two sections; the height above the substrate surface and the depth of penetration into the substrate material (remelted depth). The height above the substrate increases with increasing scan speed, whereas the opposite trend is seen with the remelted depth. This implies that further increase in scan speed might lead to a reduction in the depth of penetration sufficient to result in a lack of contact between the track and the substrate material, i.e., de-cohesion of layers from one another in 3D parts. The examined processing conditions showed no evidence of balling on the surface of the scan tracks. This indicates good wettability with the substrate material which is a crucial factor affecting the bonding of a layer to the one below (wetting in SLM, as defined by Yadroitsev et al. (2013), means that molten metal has spread over the substrate or the previous layer rather than balling).
Balling is a surface defect, among others such as satellites, that is commonly reported with SLM (Aboulkhair et al., 2014). The distinction between balling and satellites is crucial and a micrograph demonstrating the difference between them can be found in Fig. 6. The distinction between balling and satellites, in terms of morphology and microstructure, is a unique feature of this work and has not been published before. The term balling is used to refer to the formation of a large ball of material, with a fraction of this ball fully incorporated in the processed layer, i.e., the material was molten and then solidified in the form of a ball. This means that a ball is not a distinct entity on the surface but rather a form in which the surface solidified, as demonstrated in Fig. 7. Aboulkhair et al. (2014) claimed this to be scan speed dependent and is formed due to instability. A satellite on the other hand, as defined by Yadroitsev et al. (2013), is a particle sticking to the surface of the layer having contact with the scan track. It is formed by spattering or partial remelting of powder in the peripheral zone of the laser spot. The laser spatter phenomenon has been studied by Simonelli et al. (2015) who reported on the characteristic microstructure of the spatter
m w s T m s t t r
aterial and its mechanism of formation. The presence of satellites as minimal in all the tracks in this study; however, a satellite was potted on a track processed using 250 mm/s and cross-sectioned. his satellite, as can be seen in Fig. 8, was found to have a coarse icrostructure similar to the as-received powder. This supports the uggestion that satellites are formed by the spatter of particles on he single track toward the end of its solidification, with less energy ransferred to the particle; i.e., not enough to melt it and incorpoate it into the melt pool. Satellites promote the creation of pores
and worsen the surface roughness, as reported by Yadroitsev et al. (2013).
The 400 m thick powder layer yielded tracks that incorporated several defects, as can be seen in Fig. 9. At all three scan speeds, the tracks incorporated excessive balling and satellites. Although 400 m is considered a thick layer, discontinuities (if defined as absolute disconnection in the scan track, i.e., zero remelted depth) were not observed at the slowest scan speed (250 mm/s). However, discontinuities formed at 500 mm/s and 750 mm/s and yielded tracks which were just a series of droplets/balls. Although
(a) me

adroitsev et al. (2010) reported discontinuities and droplets formng at lower scan speeds, the results are not comparable to what s reported here due to the use of a different material, a much arger layer thickness, and higher laser power. When a ball is resent, minimal energy is conducted to the substrate reducing he remelted depth drastically, which results in a lack of bondng between the track and the substrate. Cross sectional views of hese tracks revealed the structure of the regions with and without alling, as shown in Fig. 10, in two different characteristic regions n the track. The stability of the melt pool is controlled by good dhesion of the melt pool to the substrate, i.e., enough depth of enetration beyond the melt pool depth and into the substrate. ome of the 250 mm/s tracks were fully consolidated into the subtrate (Fig. 10b), however, the fraction of defects formed on the urface preclude the possibility of using large layer thicknesses. he 500 and 750 mm/s tracks were either in the form of free circuar cylinders (with a large contact angle and small remelted depth) r segmental cylinders (with a smaller contact angle and larger emelted depth). For the former shape, the remelted depth was cirular whereas for the latter it was conical. Yadroitsev et al. (2010) laimed that melt pools that have the shape of segmental cylinders re more stable than free circular ones.
It was observed in the micrographs in Figs. 5 and 10 that the eight of the scan track above the substrate surface was less than he height of the deposited powder layer thickness. This can be xplained by a couple of reasons and these are:
. When the powder is irradiated by the laser beam it spreads out during melting (wetting), and so the height of the scan track will decrease alongside an increase in the width. For example in the case of using 40 m powder layer thickness (Fig. 5), the
lt pool and (b) overlapping melt pools.
spot size of the laser beam is 20 m but the width of the scan track (∼150 m) is much larger than that due to wetting and heat conduction, so instead of occupying a height of 40 m and a width of 20 m the scan track is wider with less height. Likewise, in Fig. 10, the height of the track is much less than 400 m and the width is larger than the 20 m spot size. 2. The powder packing density differs in bulk from after melting, i.e., there are gaps of trapped air between the powder particles that escape the melt pool after processing, meaning the volume occupied will decrease after processing.
3.3. Overlap of AlSi10Mg single tracks (single layers)
The hatch spacing of 50 m provided sufficient overlap between tracks at the examined scan speeds to yield an adequately consolidated layer, as no gaps can be seen on the surface of the layers in Fig. 11. This agrees with predictions based on the widths of the corresponding tracks (Fig. 5). Discoloration of the surface of the layer formed using the slowest speed (250 mm/s) was observed and attributed to prolonged exposure times and oxidation. This discoloration decreased with increasing scan speed. Oxidation is promoted at slower speeds since the material remains molten for a longer duration increasing the likelihood of oxidation, despite the relatively low oxygen content in the processing chamber. The oxygen content originally in the substrate material and the presence of moisture on the surface of the powder contributes to increasing the possibility of oxidation. As has been illustrated by Weingarten et al. (2015), upon melting the material, moisture (H2O) on the powder surface breaks down into H2 that promotes the formation of hydrogen porosity and oxygen that combines with Al, forming Al2O3.
F ositio t

ig. 16. SEM micrographs showing nano-indents and corresponding chemical comp he substrate (b)–(d).
Minimal satellites were seen on top of the 250 mm/s layer, oreover, satellites formed as the scan speed increased. In addiion, for the investigated parameters, balling on the surface did not ccur for a single layer. However, this cannot guarantee no balling hen processing a bulk sample with these parameters since balling ould occur as further layers accumulate, as has been observed in ulti-layered parts in a previous study (Aboulkhair et al., 2014) sing the same set up and parameters. Balling was present in ll layers formed from a 400 m thick powder layer, which was xpected due to the poor quality of their corresponding single racks.
The cross-sectional views of the different layers were fairly imilar in terms of being sufficiently overlapping. Examples for he 40 m and 400 m thick layers’ cross-sections are shown in ig. 12. If we consider the substrate surface as the datum, the first ew tracks were always relatively higher than the following ones, .e., the first track is higher than the second and so on. This has een previously observed for CoCrMo single layers by Pupo et al. 2013). Yadroitsev and Smurov (2011) attributed the decrease in he height of track to substrate denudation. This feature could ffect the accuracy of the parts produced by SLM. Rotating the can pattern from one layer to another, e.g., using the alternatng scan strategy (Aboulkhair et al., 2014), could be a means to emedy this surface defect, i.e., this phenomenon must be conidered when designing the scan strategy to be employed during rocessing. This is to avoid it contributing to porosity formation or roducing parts that lack dimensional accuracy. It is important to ote that porosity was not observed in any of the tracks and layers ormed in this study. This indicates that pores created in SLM parts rom AlSi10Mg are developed with layer progression, i.e., layery-layer overlap, since using the same processing parameters to
roduce multi-layered parts yielded parts with pores, as was shown y Aboulkhair et al. (2014), that were not observed in single tracks r layers.
ns across the overlapping melt pools in SLM material (a) and various regions within
3.4. Microstructure and chemical composition mapping
The melt pool of a 250 mm/s track (from a 40 m thick powder layer) had fine equiaxed cell structures at the core and coarser columnar cells at the boundary elongated in the direction of the thermal gradient, as can be seen in Fig. 13a. The overlapping melt pools had the same microstructure (Fig. 13b). An example for the chemical composition distribution within single melt pools is shown in Fig. 14. A fine microstructure with homogenous distribution of the alloying elements in the SLM material is clearly evident in the Si map. The good dispersion of the alloying elements, alongside the fine microstructure, suggests the enhanced mechanical properties required for load bearing applications. This distinctive microstructure and elemental distribution formed due to rapid solidification of the material that in turn caused structure refinement and did not allow enough time for diffusion of the alloying elements. As a result, Si was located on the boundaries of the ɑ-Al in the form of continuous segregations instead of forming particulates or flakes, such as those observed in the slowly cooled as-cast material. The border between two overlapping melt pools was relatively rich in Al compared to the rest of the melt pools, as per the micrograph in Fig. 13b.
3.5. Nanoindentation
The array of indentations on a melt pool is shown in Fig. 15a incorporating both the SLM material and the as-cast substrate. Microscopic investigation of the indentations suggests the hardness depends on the indented phase in the case of the as-cast material with its coarse microstructure. The average hardness across the SLM material was 2.4 ± 0.1 GPa, whereas that of the substrate (as-cast) material was 2.4 ± 0.4 GPa. However, the latter value is inflated by the influence of localized hardness due to the coarse microstructure. The indentations coincident on the Si flakes seen in the micrographs (Figs. 15 and 16b and d) showed

ano-hardness values ranging between 3 and 13 GPa. Excluding hese indentations, the average nano-hardness across the substrate
aterial became 1.1 ± 0.1 GPa. Numerical comparison of the overll nano-hardness of the SLM material compared to its as-cast ounterpart is not representative of the materials’ behavior. This s due to the difference in microstructure and chemical composiion distribution. The fine dispersion of the alloying elements in the LM material along with the characteristically fine microstructure esults in an improved nano-hardness, with a homogeneous prole (Aboulkhair et al., 2015). This homogeneous profile was also bserved when conducting a line of indentations across a series of verlapping melt pools in a single layer, as shown in Fig. 15b. The ariation within the profile does not show a trend with location ithin the melt pool, i.e., there was no registered trend between the ano-hardness at the melt pool boundary and core, as has been preiously reported by the authors (Aboulkhair et al., 2015), but more f a variation with the chemical elements distribution. The evoluion of nano-hardness and chemical elements distribution requires urther investigation and more results are underway and will be ubject to future publications.
Further investigation of the nano-indents using EDX clarified the elation between the chemical composition and the nano-hardness f the material. The chemical composition at different indentations s illustrated in Fig. 16. The hardness profile across the melt pool as uniform, as was the chemical composition, as seen in Fig. 16a. his finding further supports the suggestion that the rapid solidifiation of the molten material during SLM results in the formation f a fine microstructure with the alloying elements uniformly disersed. Also, the fast cooling rate does not allow sufficient time for he alloying elements (Si, Fe, and Mn) to diffuse and form flakes ike those in the as-cast regions in Figs. 16b–d. In Fig. 16b, the diference in nano-hardness between regions rich in Si and Fe and an l-rich region is shown with the latter’s nano-hardness of 0.93 GPa, hereas indenting a flake rich in Si and Fe increased the nanoardness to 3.27 GPa. A similar effect is shown in Fig. 16c but the einforcement was due to the rise in the Si content without Fe that ed to increasing the hardness but to a lesser magnitude. Fig. 16d hows the effect of Si and Fe in addition to Mn, where in this case, he nano-hardness increased to 9.73 GPa.
. Conclusions
We have conducted an investigation into the processability of he high strength alloy AlSi10Mg by selective laser melting. In paricular, we examined the formation of single scan tracks and layers, oth of which are important as they constitute the basic elements f larger consolidated SLM parts. This investigation was undertaken rincipally to elucidate the fundamental origin of porosity in SLM arts and to determine the mechanical response of SLM material at
level below the size of the melt pools. The dimensions of lines and tracks, formed by SLM, decreased inearly with increasing laser scan speed. In addition, irregulariies were observed at elevated scan speeds. The melt pools were onical rather than spherical (circular cylinder segment); a feature hat indicated the domination of keyhole mode melting. The mode f melting adopted is dictated by the physical properties of the arget material, AlSi10Mg, that influence the laser-material interction. This finding opposes results published in the literature for tainless steel, for instance, where the melt pool becomes deeper ith increasing the scan speed. The new insight grasped from this esult is that the trend of scan track dimensions with the process
arameters cannot be generalized.
There was no evidence of porosity in the cross-sections of tracks r layers, which suggests that pores form during layer accumulation
n multi-layer processing. Most studies in the literature focus on the
ocessing Technology 230 (2016) 88–98 97
formation of single tracks and multi-layered parts with very little attention to the formation of single layers. This paper, in addition to an earlier paper by the authors (Aboulkhair et al., 2014), is the first to trace the porosity development from a single track to layers and parts. There were claims that pores form based on the energy density and remain in the multi layered parts (Dai and Gu, 2014). However, these claims were based on theoretical models and not backed up with experimental evidence on single tracks or layers. This study showed experimentally that pores do not form in single tracks or layers using a pre-defined set of parameters but they do form in multi-layered samples.
The increase in layer thickness (10X) returned tracks and layers with excessive defects, such as discontinuities, irregularities, satellites, and balling. Studying a wider range of layer thicknesses to determine its effect on the produced tracks and layers requires attention in a future study. The height of a layer decreases from one track to the following one. This phenomenon needs further attention since its continuation with layer progression could affect the quality of the final product (surface roughness/alignment and dimensional accuracy). The use of an alternating scan strategy, which accounts for this phenomenon by rotating the scan direction of each layer from the preceding one, can help avoid the height variation along a layer processed by SLM.
The current study presents novel results in being the first to report on the distinct microstructure of single tracks and layers and its influence on the local mechanical properties determined by nanoindentation. The distribution of the elements in the SLM material is homogeneous, as has been demonstrated in the EDX maps, in contrast to the as-cast material. This is due to the fine microstructure and good dispersion of the alloying elements caused by rapid solidification. Such microstructure and chemical composition distribution is expected to enhance the load bearing properties of SLM parts. This was supported by the results from nanoindentation. The overall nano-hardness of the SLM material was higher and of a more uniform pattern compared to the as-cast material. Also sensitivity to indented phases that leads to spatial variation in nano-hardness was not apparent in SLM material owing to the homogenous blend of elements and the finer microstructure.

A hypothesis was suggested by Dai and Gu (2014) that pores formed during processing copper matrix composites because of trapped gases in the melt pool.

A hypothesis was suggested by Dai and Gu (2014) that pores formed during processing copper matrix composites because of trapped gases in the melt pool. This is dependent on the energy density and it was suggested that they accumulate to become porosity in the bulk samples. However, this hypothesis was not verified using experiments on single tracks to show whether pores are formed in each melt pool or during the overlap of lines and/or layers through material remelting. Nanoindentation is a depth sensing technique that is used to test mechanical properties of materials, such as nano-hardness and Young’s modulus (Fischer-Cripps, 2004). One of the characteristics of this test is that the depth of an indentation is in the micrometer range, which allows the determination of the properties of materials at a small scale. This could be beneficial in SLM due to the fine microstructure reported by Thijs et al. (2013) and distribution of phases.

The application of this technique in SLM is not yet common and it has been mainly used to test the hardness of larger bulk parts, such as the work by Biedunkiewicz et al. (2014) on metal matrix composites processed by SLM.

Balling is a surface defect, among others such as satellites, that is commonly reported with SLM (Aboulkhair et al., 2014).

This indicates good wettability with the substrate material which is a crucial factor affecting the bonding of a layer to the one below (wetting in SLM, as defined by Yadroitsev et al. (2013), means that molten metal has spread over the substrate or the previous layer rather than balling).

Balling is a surface defect, among others such as satellites, that is commonly reported with SLM (Aboulkhair et al., 2014). The distinction between balling and satellites is crucial and a micrograph demonstrating the difference between them can be found in Fig. 6. The distinction between balling and satellites, in terms of morphology and microstructure, is a unique feature of this work and has not been published before. The term balling is used to refer to the formation of a large ball of material, with a fraction of this ball fully incorporated in the processed layer, i.e., the material was molten and then solidified in the form of a ball. This means that a ball is not a distinct entity on the surface but rather a form in which the surface solidified, as demonstrated in Fig. 7. Aboulkhair et al. (2014) claimed this to be scan speed dependent and is formed due to instability.

Rotating the can pattern from one layer to another, e.g., using the alternatng scan strategy (Aboulkhair et al., 2014), could be a means to emedy this surface defect, i.e., this phenomenon must be conidered when designing the scan strategy to be employed during rocessing. This is to avoid it contributing to porosity formation or roducing parts that lack dimensional accuracy. It is important to ote that porosity was not observed in any of the tracks and layers ormed in this study. (2014), that were not observed in single tracks r layers.

This paper, in addition to an earlier paper by the authors (Aboulkhair et al., 2014), is the first to trace the porosity development from a single track to layers and parts.

metadata.abstractText: Selective laser melting (SLM) is a relatively new manufacturing technique that can be used to process a range of materials. Aluminum alloys are potential candidates for SLM but are more difficult to process than the titanium alloys more commonly used with this technique. This is because of the former’s physical properties that can result in high levels of porosity in the final parts. Although the majority of studies to date into the processing of Al alloys by SLM have considered the development of load bearing objects, in particular porosity reduction and mechanical characterization of the parts, it is also important to study the single tracks formed during the process. This paper studies the effect of changing the scan speed on the formation of fusion lines and single tracks from an Al alloy, as well as their overlap to form a single layer. The geometrical features of the melt pools as well as the boundaries of continuity and/or irregularities were defined and showed dependence on scan speed. Keyhole mode melting domination was observed. The scan tracks and layers were porosity-free suggesting pores to form with layer accumulation. Investigations showed that increasing the layer thickness should be avoided as it promoted defects. Energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) mapping was implemented to compare the chemical composition distribution in the SLM material and its as-cast counterpart. A fine microstructure with homogenous distribution of the alloying elements was observed. Nanoindentation and EDX were used to establish an understanding of the hardness profile across melt pools of single tracks and their interrelation to the chemical composition. The elemental distribution yielded uniform high nano-hardness with no spatial variation across the SLM material. © 2015 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
